items.title: Interpretable and Adaptive Node Classification on Heterophilic Graphs via Combinatorial Scoring and Hybrid Learning
items.authors: Soroush Vahidi
items.contributions: 1. Proposes an interpretable, adaptive framework for node classification using explicit combinatorial inference instead of deep message passing, with a tunable scoring function. 2. Introduces a validation-gated hybrid strategy that optionally refines combinatorial predictions with a lightweight neural model only when beneficial. 3. Ensures a leakage-free evaluation protocol by computing all adaptation signals strictly from training data.
items.summary: This paper addresses the challenge of node classification on heterophilic graphs where standard GNNs struggle. It proposes an interpretable framework based on combinatorial scoring and a conditional hybrid learning strategy, achieving competitive performance with modern GNNs while offering better interpretability, tunability, and efficiency.

items.title: Reddit Deplatforming and Toxicity Dynamics on Generalist Voat Communities
items.authors: Aleksandar Tomašević, Ana Vranić, Aleksandra Alorić, Marija Mitrović Dankulov
items.institution: Institute of Physics Belgrade, University of Belgrade
items.contributions: 1. Identifies and characterizes two distinct regimes ("Hostile Takeover" and "Toxic Equilibrium") of how deplatformed users transform receiving communities on alternative platforms. 2. Demonstrates that community transformation is driven by peripheral dynamics and volume, not by newcomers capturing central network positions. 3. Shows that the structure of the migrating community (loose vs. cohesive) determines whether they disperse into generalist spaces or form dedicated enclaves.
items.summary: This paper studies how Reddit deplatforming affects the communities on the alternative platform Voat. Using network analysis, toxicity detection, and dynamic reputation modeling, it finds that migration leads to increased toxicity through distinct phases and that platforms have a narrow window to intervene before toxic norms become entrenched.

items.title: BLISS: Bandit Layer Importance Sampling Strategy for Efficient Training of Graph Neural Networks
items.authors: Omar Alsaqa, Linh Thi Hoang, Muhammed Fatih Balin
items.institution: Wilfrid Laurier University, Singapore Management University, Georgia Institute of Technology
items.contributions: 1. Introduces BLISS, a novel adaptive sampling strategy using multi-armed bandits to dynamically select informative nodes at each GNN layer. 2. Balances exploration and exploitation to ensure comprehensive graph coverage and adapts to evolving node importance, unlike static methods. 3. Demonstrates versatility by integrating with different GNN architectures (GCNs and GATs) and maintaining or exceeding full-batch training accuracy.
items.summary: The paper addresses the computational bottleneck in training Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) on large graphs by proposing BLISS, a Bandit Layer Importance Sampling Strategy. BLISS uses multi-armed bandits to dynamically and adaptively sample the most informative nodes at each layer. Experiments show that this method maintains or even surpasses the accuracy of full-batch training while being more efficient.

items.title: Periodical embeddings uncover hidden interdisciplinary patterns in the subject classification scheme of science
items.authors: Zhuoqi Lyu, Qing Ke
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a novel quantitative framework that uses classification tasks to evaluate the effectiveness of journal classification schemes. 2. Introduces Periodical2Vec (P2V), a periodical embedding method learned from paper-level citations, which outperforms existing schemes. 3. Uncovers structural patterns in the map of science, such as the reorganization of disciplinary boundaries and the identification of coherent interdisciplinary clusters.
items.summary: The paper addresses the limitations of traditional subject classification schemes by proposing a data-driven framework using Periodical2Vec embeddings derived from citation networks. It demonstrates that this method yields more accurate journal classifications than expert-curated systems like Scopus and reveals a more nuanced, interdisciplinary map of science.

items.title: A new adaptive two-layer model for opinion spread in hypergraphs: parameter sensitivity and estimation
items.authors: Ágnes Backhausz, Villő Csiszár, Balázs Csegő Kolok, Damján Tárkányi, András Zempléni
items.institution: ELTE Eötvös Loránd University, HUN-REN Alfred Rényi Institute of Mathematics
items.contributions: 1. Introduces a novel two-layer adaptive hypergraph model for opinion spread, incorporating higher-order interactions in households and workplaces. 2. Analyzes the model's sensitivity to key parameters (opinion change and workplace quitting probabilities) on homophily and polarization speed, and studies it as a Markov chain. 3. Compares the performance of statistical and machine learning methods (linear regression, xgboost, CNN) for estimating model parameters from partial observational data.
items.summary: This paper proposes a new adaptive hypergraph model to simulate opinion spread, where individuals can change their opinion or switch workplaces based on group majority. Through simulations and Markov chain analysis, the authors study how parameters affect polarization. They also evaluate different machine learning methods for estimating these parameters from limited data, finding that all can be effective depending on the strength of peer pressure.

items.title: Beyond-Diagonal Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces for 6G Networks: Principles, Challenges, and Quantum Horizons
items.authors: Abd Ullah Khan, Uman Khalid, Muhammad Tanveer, Trung Q. Duong, Hyundong Shin
items.institution: Kyung Hee University, University of Management and Technology, Memorial University of Newfoundland, Queen's University Belfast
items.contributions: 1. Provides a systematic introduction to Beyond-Diagonal Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (BD-RIS), detailing its principles, architecture, advantages, and classification. 2. Presents a case study comparing four beamforming algorithms for BD-RIS, analyzing their performance in terms of sum rate and computation cost. 3. Proposes and analyzes hybrid quantum-classical machine learning models to enhance beam prediction for 6G BD-RIS, validated using the real-world DeepSense 6G dataset.
items.summary: This paper introduces Beyond-Diagonal Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (BD-RIS) as a key technology for 6G networks to overcome high-frequency propagation challenges. It systematically reviews BD-RIS principles, analyzes beamforming algorithms, and explores quantum-enhanced machine learning for beam prediction. The work concludes with insights into the practical implications and future potential of BD-RIS for advanced wireless communication.

items.title: Information is localized in growing network models
items.authors: Till Hoffmann, Jukka-Pekka Onnela
items.institution: Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health
items.contributions: 1. Theoretically establishes that information about model parameters is localized in small subgraphs for a broad class of growing network models. 2. Develops neural density estimators (NDEs) using graph neural networks (GNNs) with limited receptive fields to approximate posterior distributions for likelihood-free inference. 3. Empirically validates the localization theory on nine models and shows NDEs can achieve high-fidelity inference even for non-localized models at a fraction of the cost.
items.summary: This paper addresses the challenge of intractable likelihoods in mechanistic growing network models. It proposes that information about model parameters is localized in small subgraphs and leverages this by developing neural density estimators based on graph neural networks with limited receptive fields for Bayesian inference. The main conclusion is that information localization is a fundamental property of network growth, justifying the use of local subgraph analysis and limited-receptive-field GNNs for efficient and accurate inference.

items.title: R&D Networks under Heterogeneous Firm Productivities
items.authors: M. Sadra Heydari, Zafer Kanik, Santiago Montoya-Blandón
items.institution: University of Glasgow (Adam Smith Business School)
items.contributions: 1. Introduces heterogeneous R&D productivities into an endogenous R&D network formation model, generalizing a classic framework. 2. Shows that large productivity gaps destabilize the complete network and make positive assortative (PA) networks stable, overturning benchmark results. 3. Demonstrates a counterintuitive welfare result where higher average productivity can lead to lower welfare due to network structure changes and crowding-out effects.
items.summary: This paper extends an R&D network formation model by incorporating heterogeneous firm productivities. It finds that large productivity differences lead to the instability of fully connected networks and the stability of networks where firms cluster by productivity (Positive Assortative networks). The key conclusion is that higher average R&D productivity can paradoxically reduce overall welfare by inducing less efficient network structures or crowding out effects.

items.title: SENTINEL: A Multi-Modal Early Detection Framework for Emerging Cyber Threats using Telegram
items.authors: Mohammad Hammas Saeed, Howie Huang
items.contributions: 1. Proposes SENTINEL, a multi-modal framework for early cyber threat detection by aligning social media discussions with real-world attacks. 2. Combines language modeling (using LLMs) and network coordination analysis (using GNNs) to fuse textual and relational signals from platforms like Telegram. 3. Demonstrates the framework's effectiveness on a dataset of 365k messages from 16 Telegram channels, achieving an F1 score of 0.89 for threat alignment.
items.summary: The paper presents SENTINEL, a framework for the early detection of cyber threats by analyzing multi-modal signals from social media platforms like Telegram. It combines large language models for text understanding with graph neural networks to model user coordination, successfully aligning online discussions to real-world attacks. The evaluation on Telegram data shows the approach is effective, achieving a high F1 score of 0.89.

items.title: ALETHEIA: Combating Social Media Influence Campaigns with Graph Neural Networks
items.authors: Mohammad Hammas Saeed, Isaiah J. King, Howie Huang
items.contributions: 1. Proposes ALETHEIA, a system that formalizes the detection of malicious accounts in influence campaigns as a node classification and link prediction problem using a graph-based representation. 2. Demonstrates that a detection pipeline combining topological (graph) and linguistic features outperforms standard interaction and user features, achieving a 3.7% F1-score improvement. 3. Introduces a novel temporal link prediction mechanism for influence campaigns by stacking a GNN over an RNN to forecast future troll interactions (TTE/TUE) with high accuracy (96.6% AUC).
items.summary: This paper presents ALETHEIA, a system that uses Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to detect malicious accounts and predict their future interactions in social media influence campaigns. By modeling campaigns as graphs and combining structural and linguistic features, it improves detection performance and forecasts troll behavior with high accuracy. The results underscore the importance of leveraging network structure to combat coordinated malicious activity online.

items.title: Multiconnectivity for SAGIN: Current Trends, Challenges, AI-driven Solutions, and Opportunities
items.authors: Abd Ullah Khan, Adnan Shahid, Haejoon Jung, Hyundong Shin
items.contributions: 1. Provides a comprehensive review of current developments and key implementation challenges in SAGIN-enabled multiconnectivity. 2. Highlights the transformative potential of AI-driven approaches, particularly agentic reinforcement learning, for resource optimization in heterogeneous SAGIN environments. 3. Presents a case study demonstrating that learning-based methods can effectively enhance network performance (latency, capacity) with a moderate trade-off in power consumption.
items.summary: This paper reviews the challenges of implementing multiconnectivity in heterogeneous Space-Air-Ground Integrated Networks (SAGIN) and proposes AI-driven solutions, specifically agentic reinforcement learning, for optimal resource allocation. A case study shows these methods significantly improve latency and capacity, albeit with a moderate increase in power consumption as a trade-off. The work concludes by outlining open research problems for realizing efficient SAGIN-enabled multiconnectivity.

items.title: Beyond Content: How Author Network Centrality Drives Citation Disparities in Top AI Conferences
items.authors: Renlong Jie, Longfeng Zhao, Chen Chu, Danyang Jia, Zhen Wang
items.institution: Northwestern Polytechnical University, Yunnan University of Finance and Economics
items.contributions: 1. Proposed a novel centrality metric (Harmonic Closeness with Temporal and Collaboration Count Decay - HCTCD) that incorporates temporal decay and collaboration intensity. 2. Advanced the methodological field by employing beta regression to model citation percentiles, appropriately handling the bounded nature of citation data. 3. Demonstrated that team-level centrality aggregation, particularly through exponentially weighted summation, explains citation variance more effectively than individual or rank-based approaches, highlighting the importance of collective network connectivity.
items.summary: This study investigates how authors' positions in scientific collaboration networks influence citation disparities in top AI conferences. It proposes a new centrality metric (HCTCD) and uses beta regression to analyze data from NeurIPS, ICML, and ICLR. The findings show that long-term network centrality, especially at the team level, is a strong predictor of citations, challenging evaluation paradigms that focus solely on content.

items.title: Heterogeneous fragmentation of empty sites promotes cooperation in phenotypically diverse populations with tag-mediated interactions
items.authors: Hui Zhang, Tarik Hadzibeganovic, Xiao-Pu Han
items.institution: Northwestern Polytechnical University, University of Graz, Hangzhou Normal University
items.contributions: 1. Developed a spatially explicit agent-based model to study the interplay between habitat fragmentation, phenotypic diversity, and the evolution of cooperation. 2. Demonstrated that heterogeneous fragmentation of empty sites, combined with high phenotypic diversity and low cost-to-benefit ratios, suppresses ethnocentric cooperation while promoting unconditional altruism. 3. Showcased the "anti-fragility" of cooperators, revealing they can benefit from harsh environmental conditions in fragmented, phenotypically diverse populations.
items.summary: This paper investigates how habitat fragmentation and phenotypic diversity influence the evolution of cooperation using a spatially explicit agent-based model based on the Snowdrift game. The simulations show that a combination of high phenotypic diversity, low interaction costs, and moderate fragmentation of empty sites strongly promotes unconditional cooperation while suppressing conditional, ethnocentric strategies. The main conclusion is that heterogeneous habitat fragmentation can act as a potent cooperation-promoting mechanism, demonstrating the resilience of cooperators in degraded environments.

items.authors: Danila Valko, Jorge Marx Gómez
items.institution: Carl von Ossietzky Universität Oldenburg, OFFIS – Institute for Information Technology
items.contributions: 1. Provides a comprehensive analysis of the Lightning Network's topology using 47 metrics over a five-year dataset (2019-2023). 2. Quantifies the network's topological stability over time, offering new insights into its structural evolution. 3. Derives implications for the design of heuristic-based pathfinding and routing protocols in Payment Channel Networks.
items.summary: This paper conducts a comprehensive temporal analysis of the Lightning Network's topology using a five-year dataset. By computing 47 network metrics, it characterizes the network's structure and evolution, quantifying its topological stability. The findings support the design of improved routing protocols and provide a detailed characterization for future network science research.

Proposal of a principled GNN architecture specifically tailored for the source detection task. 3. A systematic benchmark study demonstrating that GNNs substantially outperform traditional source detection methods across various network types, and advocating for epidemic source detection as a benchmark task for evaluating GNN architectures.
items.summary: This paper reviews Graph Neural Network (GNN) approaches for detecting the source of an epidemic in a network, proposes a new GNN architecture for the task, and conducts a benchmark study. The experiments show that GNNs significantly outperform traditional methods like rumor centrality, establishing them as highly effective for source detection and suggesting the task as a standard benchmark for GNN evaluation.

items.title: Signal, Noise, and Burnout: A Human-Information Interaction Analysis of Voter Verification in a High-Volatility Environment
items.authors: Kijung Lee
items.institution: (Institution not explicitly stated in provided content; author name "Kijung Lee" present but no affiliation/email domain. Based on data source, likely an academic institution collaborating with Pew Research Center.)
items.contributions: 1. Empirically tests the relationship between information source (social media vs. mainstream news) and perceived verification difficulty (epistemic self-efficacy) during a high-volatility election. 2. Identifies perceived exposure to inaccurate information as a mediator and information fatigue as a key moderator in the verification process. 3. Challenges platform-deterministic theories by finding that demographics and universal information fatigue, not platform type, are primary drivers of epistemic burden in volatile environments.
items.summary: This study analyzes how voters perceive their ability to verify news (epistemic self-efficacy) during the volatile 2024 U.S. election, using survey data to test hypotheses about information sources, misinformation exposure, and fatigue. Contrary to expectations, it finds no significant difference in verification difficulty between social media and mainstream news users, concluding that cognitive factors like universal information fatigue are more critical than platform choice.

items.authors: Dino Husnic, Stefan Cobeli, Shweta Yadav

Correlated the temporal trends of emotional and mental health-related self-disclosure on social media with key UK policy dates. 3. Provided a proof-of-concept demonstrating that incorporating mental health features can improve emotion prediction accuracy.
items.summary: This study analyzes emotions and mental health self-disclosure on the r/unitedkingdom subreddit during the early COVID-19 pandemic. Using a soft labeling technique on Reddit data, the authors correlate emotional trends with key policy dates and demonstrate that mental health features can enhance emotion prediction accuracy.

items.title: Emotion Diffusion in Real and Simulated Social Graphs: Structural Limits of LLM-Based Social Simulation
items.authors: Qiqi Qiang
items.institution: (Institution not explicitly stated in provided content. Based on author name "Qiang Qiqi", it is not possible to reliably infer an institution without an email domain or affiliation section. Output left blank.)
items.contributions: 1. Conducted a systematic structural and dynamic comparison between emotion diffusion in real-world social graphs (from Reddit) and LLM-simulated interaction networks. 2. Identified key structural discrepancies: real graphs show dense connectivity and sentiment shifts, while simulated graphs are largely isolated linear chains with monotonic emotions. 3. Demonstrated that these structural limitations in LLM-simulated graphs negatively impact downstream tasks like graph-based emotion prediction, reducing emotional diversity.
items.summary: This paper compares emotion diffusion patterns in real social media graphs and those generated by LLM-based simulations. The method involves constructing and analyzing diffusion graphs from Reddit data and LLM-simulated conversations using sentiment analysis. The main conclusion is that current LLM-based social simulations fail to capture the interactive complexity and emotional heterogeneity of real networks, leading to structurally simplistic and less useful synthetic graphs.

items.title: A Community-Enhanced Graph Representation Model for Link Prediction
items.authors: Lei Wang, Darong Lai
items.contributions: 1. Proposes a Community-Enhanced Link Prediction (CELP) framework that integrates community structure to jointly model local and global graph topology. 2. Introduces a graph enhancement technique via community-aware, confidence-guided edge completion and pruning. 3. Integrates multi-scale structural features to improve link prediction accuracy, with experimental validation showing superior performance.
items.summary: The paper addresses the limitation of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) in link prediction, where they often underperform traditional heuristic methods due to over-reliance on local information. It proposes the CELP framework, which incorporates community structure to enhance the graph and capture multi-scale features. Experimental results show CELP achieves superior performance, validating the importance of community structure for accurate link prediction.

items.title: Bots Don't Sit Still: A Longitudinal Study of Bot Behaviour Change, Temporal Drift, and Feature-Structure Evolution
items.authors: Ohoud Alzahrani, Russell Beale, Bob Hendley
items.summary: This paper conducts a longitudinal study analyzing the temporal behavior of promotional Twitter bots using time series analysis and statistical tests on ten content-based meta-features. It finds that bot behavior is non-stationary, with individual features and their interdependencies evolving systematically over time and across bot generations. The conclusion is that bot-detection systems must account for this dynamic adaptation and avoid treating behavioral features as static.

items.title: Privacy-Preserving Synthetic Dataset of Individual Daily Trajectories for City-Scale Mobility Analytics
items.authors: Jun'ichi Ozaki, Ryosuke Susuta, Takuhiro Moriyama, Yohei Shida
items.institution: Not explicitly provided; cannot infer from given information.
tags: universal law of daily visited locations
items.summary: This paper proposes a method to generate a privacy-preserving synthetic dataset of individual daily trajectories by integrating aggregated origin-destination flows with behavioral constraints in a multi-objective optimization framework. The method successfully reproduces realistic human mobility patterns in two Japanese regions, providing a practical pathway for high-resolution mobility analytics without using sensitive personal data.

items.title: Social Story Frames: Contextual Reasoning about Narrative Intent and Reception
items.authors: Joel Mire, Maria Antoniak, Steven R. Wilson, Zexin Ma, Achyutarama R. Ganti, Andrew Piper, Maarten Sap
items.institution: Carnegie Mellon University, University of Colorado Boulder, University of Michigan-Flint, University of Connecticut, McGill University
items.summary: This paper introduces SocialStoryFrames, a formalism and computational framework for modeling nuanced reader responses to social media stories, including inferences about author intent and affective reactions. It develops two models (SSF-Generator and SSF-Classifier) and applies them to a corpus of online narratives to analyze storytelling practices across communities. The main conclusion is that this approach enables scalable, context-sensitive research into the social dynamics of online storytelling.

items.title: Promoting Fairness in Information Access within Social Networks
items.authors: Changan Liu, Xiaotian Zhou, Ahad N. Zehmakan, Zhongzhi Zhang
items.summary: The paper proposes a method to enhance fairness in information access within social networks by adding new connections, formulated as an optimization problem using resistance distance. The main technical contribution is a linear-time algorithm that reduces the complexity of a greedy approach, enabling accurate solutions for large networks with millions of nodes.

items.title: The Graph-Embedded Hazard Model (GEHM): Stochastic Network Survival Dynamics on Economic Graphs
items.authors: Diego Vallarino
items.summary: This paper proposes a Graph-Embedded Hazard Model (GEHM), a nonlinear PDE-SDE framework that couples graph-based p-Laplacian diffusion with stochastic drift to model survival dynamics on economic networks. The main conclusion is that hub dominance in networks like Barabási–Albert magnifies nonlinear gradients, compresses stability margins, and leads to heavy-tailed survival distributions with occasional explosive behavior.

items.title: Tourists Profiling by Interest Analysis
items.authors: Sonia Djebali, Quentin Gabot, Guillaume Guerard
items.summary: This paper proposes a method that uses both qualitative and quantitative analysis of digital traces from social networks to profile tourists. It employs graph models and community detection techniques to analyze geo-located data and understand tourist behavior dynamics within attraction networks. The main conclusion is that this combined approach provides a deeper understanding of tourist interests and movement patterns compared to purely quantitative studies.

items.title: SoMe: A Realistic Benchmark for LLM-based Social Media Agents
items.authors: Dizhan Xue, Jing Cui, Shengsheng Qian, Chuanrui Hu, Changsheng Xu
items.institution: Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences; Tianjin University of Technology; Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications; Peng Cheng Laboratory
items.summary: This paper introduces SoMe, a comprehensive benchmark for evaluating LLM-based social media agents across diverse tasks using real social media data and agent tools. The evaluation shows that current LLMs, both closed and open-source, perform unsatisfactorily on these realistic social media agent tasks. SoMe serves as a challenging testbed to advance future social media agent development.

items.title: Compute the edge p-Laplacian centrality for air traffic network
items.authors: Loc Hoang Tran, Bao Nguyen Tran, Luong Anh Tuan Nguyen
items.summary: This paper proposes a method to compute edge p-Laplacian centrality for an air traffic network by first converting the network into a line graph and then computing the node p-Laplacian centrality on that line graph. The method is based on a novel un-normalized graph p-Laplacian operator. The experimental results show that this ranking method can be successfully implemented.

items.title: Cyberswarm: a novel swarm intelligence algorithm inspired by cyber community dynamics
items.authors: Abdelsadeq Elfergany, Ammar Adl, Mohammed Kayed
items.summary: The paper introduces Cyberswarm, a general-purpose swarm intelligence algorithm for recommendation systems that models user preferences and community influences using a dynamic hypergraph structure with techniques like Node2Vec and message-passing. Experimental results show it outperforms baseline methods on metrics like HR, MRR, and NDCG across various tasks. The work demonstrates the effectiveness of integrating swarm intelligence with network dynamics for adaptive and precise recommendations.

items.title: Model inference for ranking from pairwise comparisons
items.authors: Daniel Sánchez Catalina, George T. Cantwell
items.summary: This paper presents an efficient Bayesian algorithm to jointly infer both the latent strengths of objects and the unknown function mapping strengths to win probabilities from pairwise comparison data. The method uses Chebyshev-based and neural network approaches to model this function without prior assumptions. Experimental results show robustness across model specifications and improved predictive accuracy, such as overcoming bookmaker profit margins in tennis data.
